Glasses

Jan 29, 2008

Poetry poems glasses perspective eyes

I once wore glasses
Sometimes I still do
When I would go outside,
on a cold winters day,
they would fog over;
blinding me.

So I removed them, changed lenses
with new ones placed into my eyes,
not in front of them.
Now I see differently, but the same.

I have tried many different lenses in 35 years.
Some dried and clouded faster than others.
Some caused my vision to deteriorate even further.
A few even caused my sight to flip-flop:
my right eye took on the prescription of the left.

It seems it’s time for a new prescription,
which necessitates an evaluation as well.
What will be the verdict?

Am I better off or worse than before?
What correction is needed
so that I may see clearly again;
as cleanly, clearly as perhaps I
only last did upon exiting the womb?

Get real, self.
These eyes are not old, but are getting older.
They still see clearly, yet it’s true that while
each year brings a stronger prescription
to focus these eyes, I can still see clearly.
I guess that’s all that really matters.
That is, until someday
I’m blinded once again.
